body:
r? @pnkfelix

(rust_highfive has picked a reviewer for you, use r? to override)

cc @nikomatsakis
If libsyntax still has unit tests, could they be moved to `src/test/run-pass-fulldeps/`, where this PR adds a few tests invoking libsyntax?
It seems much cleaner than unit tests, and fixing them doesn't trigger a libsyntax rebuild (though that's just a minor annoyance that is solved by `touch`-ing a file into the past).
Is there a feature gate? It doesn't look like it from the tests, but it should have one.
Oh! Right, feature gate. Where do I add that?
https://dxr.mozilla.org/rust/source/src/libsyntax/feature_gate.rs

It might be good to do a few measurements of this along the lines of:
- Does this increase memory usage of compiling large programs like the compiler?
- Does this slow down passes because of larger nodes? (I would suspect no)
- An interesting project would be to attempt to put this into src/grammar before going too much farther (but it probably fits ok)

Thanks for the impl regardless @Kimundi!

Here's the result of compiling `librustc` with and without this patch:

![chart](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2903206/11182002/9bd67240-8c67-11e5-8878-e76b9e6fc8b8.png)

Question about macros: is `#[allow(wormholes)] 1 + 1` matched by `$e:expr`, `#[$attr:meta] $e:expr`, both, or neither?

Also, the trailing expression thing seems like it might be nice to get working, because `let foo = { #[cfg(bar)] 1 #[cfg(not(bar))] 2};` seems like it could be useful (eye-bleeding notwithstanding), and if this gets merged with the result of that being `foo == ()` then it would be a breaking change to "fix" it later. Though I guess you could maybe simulate it with something like `let foo = { (#[cfg(bar)] 1, #[cfg(not(bar))] 2, ).0 };`.

Good question about the macro case! I'm guessing it counts as the latter if that macro syntax is legal today, I'd have to test it.

And yeah, the more I think about it the more I think the trailing case should just be made to work as expected. (Though its indeed simulatable today)
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #29903) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

Okay, I added the feature gate and rebased on upstream changes.

@durka I tested the macro case, and it will accept both, depending only on order of the macro clauses. Not sure if that is an issue regarding macro stability...
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30015) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@Kimundi I dunno about future-proofing, but I think that is the best outcome in terms of macro writing. Because by switching the order of macro arms, you can choose whether you want to match "any expr, with or without attrs" or catch the attr (in order to implement custom attrs or something).

Okay this change looks good to me overall.

@Kimundi do you know if the changes you have made to various API's needs to be considered a breaking change with respect to external tools making use of `libsyntax`?  (cc @nrc)

Hm, I was under the assumption that `libsyntax` is unstable. I guess the addition of attribute fields and arguments will break some code that construct ASTs manually, same for some of the parser changes.
(Nominating for discussion about definition if "breaking change" at compiler team mtg)
@bors r+

:pushpin: Commit 3f33cbc has been approved by `pnkfelix`

<!-- @bors r=pnkfelix 3f33cbcbff47182fef3437040c301c8ea30a5afc -->
:hourglass: Testing commit 3f33cbc with merge 18528e7...
:broken_heart: Test failed - [auto-linux-musl-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-musl-64-opt/builds/2422)
Apparently rpass-fulldeps tests that want to make use of compiler libraries need to be ignored for cross compile testing. I pushed a fix, hopefully it works now.
@bors r=pnkfelix

:pushpin: Commit d06f480 has been approved by `pnkfelix`

<!-- @bors r=pnkfelix d06f48054cefec1fdb87e9c9196ce1f2a31c2a9f -->
:hourglass: Testing commit d06f480 with merge 77ed39c...

:sunny: Test successful - [auto-linux-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-nopt-t/builds/7291), [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/7306), [auto-linux-64-debug-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-debug-opt/builds/564), [auto-linux-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-nopt-t/builds/7245), [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/7266), [auto-linux-64-x-android-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-x-android-t/builds/7252), [auto-linux-cross-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-cross-opt/builds/477), [auto-linux-musl-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-musl-64-opt/builds/2429), [auto-mac-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-32-opt/builds/7321), [auto-mac-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-nopt-t/builds/7312), [auto-mac-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-opt/builds/7278), [auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-nopt-t/builds/2276), [auto-win-gnu-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-32-opt/builds/2281), [auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-nopt-t/builds/2283), [auto-win-gnu-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-gnu-64-opt/builds/2273), [auto-win-msvc-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-msvc-32-opt/builds/1530), [auto-win-msvc-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-msvc-64-opt/builds/2264)

Holy shit, it broke 4 of my 5 pending PRs :D
I suppose it will break plenty of plugins generating pieces of AST or overriding folder methods, so marking this with [breaking-change] would be helpful.

@petrochenkov yeah we debated this at the compiler team mtg; niko and I weren't sure changing libsyntax like this should be categorized as "breaking" the way other changes are. I guess I still might have injected the breaking-change text, I don't know, we didn't come up with a firm rule

FTR, I think breaking changes to libsyntax should be marked `[breaking-change]` (some but not all have been in the past). I do think this clearly passes the test for benefit outweighs the cost of breakage.
This broke `json_macros`, although the fix was pretty simple. https://github.com/tomjakubowski/json_macros/commit/7ada367e294f0694d86180184da2eac274677826
